content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.
This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "REVERSE" option has therefore been deactivated.

Fun clash. Nice job.  It may be trickier without a knowledge of tennis, but probably still solvable.

Here is my code in ruby for fun.  I wrote two version, the first figured out the score after every serve.  Then I realized I only need to know the second to last serve to know the answer.  Here is my second version of the code:

n=gets.to_i
serve=[*$<][-2].chomp  # Get second to last serve
a=[4,(n/2)+1].max
b=n-a
scores=[a,b]
scores.reverse! if serve == "ad-out" || serve=~/^(0|15|30)/  # Switch if ad-out or 0,15 or 30 first score
puts scores*?-

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Maybe this problem is better as puzzle (easy), too many variables for a clash of code challenge.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I think this one is really cool. Approved!
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Does the same player serve for the entire game? I'm unfamiliar with tennis rules - I play a sport where the winner of each point serves the next point (so the score might go 2-0, 3-0, 1-3)

Mix up which player wins in the tests vs validators. Right now I can ignore all the in/out scores and just have the player on the left always win.

I would say at the statement that in tennis the score increments 4 times (15,30,40,45). If the player gets to 45 points then the player wins the game and it will displayed as 'game'. If both players are draw (both with 40 points) it will be displayed as 'deuce'. Between 'deuce' and 'game',  to win the game the player will have to win 2 points. The first point will be displayed as 'advantage'. If the player with the advantage wins the point, it will be displayed as 'game' else it will come back to 'deuce'.

0 => 15 => 30 => 40 => game

deuce <=> advantage <=> game 

I would put the focus for example, if having a certain scoreboard, the game could be win with any of the players. The way it's requested the output to be printed right now, it's not clear at all.
I agree with mihei, and also it is way too hard

With such statement it's no easier than reverse. No explanation how tennis score counts (what means 15, 30, 40, "game", "deuse", etc), no constraints and expected inputs.
Should we google the whole tennis rules to solve this?

I assumed that tennis is popular enough that everyone would be familiar with it. But as someone who plays tennis, I'm probably biased.
Added in some explanations on scoring, expected inputs, and constraints.

Thank you for your help. English is not my 1st language so I would really appreciate any help in making the statement clearer.
I really liked the chart that shows how the score flows, so I added it to the statement.
Could you please give me an example of a scoreboard where the outcome would be uncertain?
The problem with displaying the point as 'advantage' is that we don't know whether the server or the receiver is having the 'advantage'. 
Also, isn't it confusing to say that the score can be incremented 4 times because we might run into a deuce situation, in which the score can go back and forth infinitely?

Thank you for the comment!
Yep the same player does serve for the entire game. The players switch serve after someone wins the game.
Thank you for sharing your solution!
